author: effystonem92
content: This is completely normal, it can even reflect positively showing that you’re in demand! Take this with a grain of salt as it's just my two cents but it's common for people to RSVP “yes” to multiple events and attend portions of each. In the meantime, it’s a good idea to reach out to the organisers and ask whether recordings will be available for any parts you might miss due to other information sessions scheduled that evening. You don’t need to mention which firms, as that’s honestly none of their business, but do clarify that the conflict is due to overlapping information nights, so they don’t mistakenly assume it’s a work/uni-related absence.

author: effystonem92
content:
My general two cents – while informal sessions like coffee catchups or information sessions aren’t formally assessed in the same way as interviews, it’s still important to approach every part of the process with care and professionalism. Things like being responsive over email, showing reasonable availability (we don’t expect you to clear your schedules by any means but it doesn’t leave a great impression when candidates say their only availability in the next three weeks is 31 July 2025 5:55pm to 6:10pm), and being present and engaged during interactions does make a difference.
While these informal touchpoints typically aren’t deal-breakers on their own, they do form part of the broader impression we provide back to the recruitment team. We’re generally asked to report back on things like attitude, preparedness, and overall enthusiasm. Turning up late to a one-on-one catchup, asking silly questions that could have been Googled beforehand at an information evening, or drinking too much at a networking event and calling a partner a corporate square (just why?!) is going to leave a negative impression, especially when compared to candidates who are making the effort.
That said, life happens, and extenuating circumstances are absolutely understood. For example, I knew someone who had to miss a few sessions after getting their wisdom teeth removed – HR across multiple firms made it abundantly clear they didn’t want them showing up fresh out of surgery. Firms also know that you’ll have competing events – it’s about the overall effort and attitude. So if something comes up, don’t stress, just make sure to communicate clearly and proactively. The main thing is that under no circumstances should you fail to follow up after committing to attend or ghost them hoping it'll go unnoticed. It not only comes across as disrespectful to those who’ve set aside time for you, it gives the impression that you’re unreliable or do not follow through on your word (which is at the end of the day, all we've really got).

author: Sprayandpray
content:
There’s probably a lot more that go into it than grades. I’m definitely not an expert in recruitment but was lucky enough to progress despite weaker grades. It probably depends on how you portrayed your t6 experience – did you take on “substantive” responsibilities in a “substantive” team (used very loosely). E.g., perhaps a paralegal role in the DR team may have given you more exposure to drafting/research than an intern role in one of the technology teams – not saying you don’t learn much in these teams, I’m sure you did and you will, but you’d likely do more research or drafting in the DR team (again, comes down to how you portray your experience).
I’ve also been told other factors may include your ECs (did you have leadership positions or do comps) and whether you demonstrated a genuine interest in the application, sometimes saying “I’m really interested in X” isn’t enough, you’d probably have to mention an ongoing case the firm’s taking, who the partner taking the lead is and why that case is interesting to you.
- Just my two cents, probably doesn’t mean much but hope it helps you get a peace of mind. I also don’t think the “oh that firm only hires a certain type” is a good mentality to have. I’m sure most don’t.

author: effystonem92
content:
Just a few more thoughts based on my own experience going through the clerkship process and now being on the other side of it:
In general, a law WAM of 75+ tends to put you in a strong position for HSF, Allens, and KWM, and a WAM of 70+ is typically considered competitive for the other firms. That said, these are absolutely not hard cut-offs, just rough guidelines. The perception that being at a Go8 university gives you an edge is outdated (as someone who went to one, this isn’t a cope). Firms are increasingly aware that university choice is often shaped by access and privilege at the high school level, and they don't moderate marks based on your university. A 75 is a 75, regardless of where you studied. For those who don’t believe me, if you stalk previous recent clerk cohorts at the big firms on LinkedIn, you’ll see a really sizeable portion did not study at a Go8.
In terms of work experience, firms generally just want to see that you’ve had some – it doesn’t need to be with a T6 firm or even a legal role. They’re aware that highly sought-after paralegal experience can sometimes come down to nepotism or connections, and they don’t necessarily see it as a marker of pure merit (that is not to say you haven’t worked hard, it’s just something to keep in mind – on LinkedIn, you can see a lot of summer clerks have only worked in hospitality/retail before commencing). In fact, if you already have a T6 paralegal role or are perceived as highly likely to go to the best firms, some firms might choose not to invest time interviewing you (as for partners, they’re forgoing $1,000ph), as they’re trying to protect their yield and conversion rates. Furthermore, you also don’t need to have elite-level extracurriculars like Jessup mooting or Law Journal. For example, I know someone who received multiple top-tier offers whose application centred around their passion as a pole dancing instructor. Firms just want to see some engagement outside of your studies.
Once you've met the basic thresholds – a reasonable WAM, some work experience, and some form of extracurricular involvement – one of the biggest differentiators becomes the quality of your written application. Crafting strong applications are an art in themselves and the writing style is quite specific and can take time to master, so please do not beat yourself up, it’s not a reflection on you or your capabilities or potential. It’s also true that each firm tends to look for a certain type of candidate – not just in terms of qualifications, but personality and “fit”. The best analogy I can offer is that it’s a bit like fraternity or sorority rush – while the process may seem uniform on the surface, each firm has its own distinct culture and tends to gravitate toward a specific “vibe” in candidates eg. one firm I'm thinking of tends to take nerds who are the type to genuinely enjoy talking about constitutional law at lunch, another firm I'm thinking of has a big work hard party hard culture and is quite jock-y in their intake etc.

author: mikoraiden
content:
I honestly do not believe Uni and WAM is everything, especially in 2025 lol. My friend who clerked at KWM last year went to MQ with a WAM of 74. While she had extensive legal experience at a Mid-tier firm and extra-curricular, she actually received offers from all of the T06 except Allens.
I'm not too sure what recruiters are genuinely looking for, but thinking a firm only accepts a TO8 University (UTS isn't that far behind), is a pretty outdated view, I'm pretty sure Allens in the only firm that cares about that. Firms are trying to be more progressive and inclusive.
My point essentially is don't think firms narrow down applicants based solely on your university or WAM (albeit your WAM is below 70, though I have heard of a clerk getting into B&B with a passing WAM – not sure at all how he made it).

author: Mike Wazowski
content:
In the interest of discussion, I disagree. UTS is known for having multiple choice exams and assignments vs USYD which literally has in-paper and sometimes closed book exams. The rigour of the academic process of these universities should not be discounted. Firms are 100% doing better to take into account disadvantage, which is great. However, I think to say that a 75 is a 75 regardless of where you study in a farce.
I do largely agree with the following points, where you study alone will not discount you, however, I do think where you study is part of the consideration process.
mikoraiden writes...
My point essentially is don't think firms narrow down applicants based solely on your university or WAM (albeit your WAM is below 70, though I have heard of a clerk getting into B&B with a passing WAM – not sure at all how he made it)
effystonem92 writes...
Once you've met the basic thresholds – a reasonable WAM, some work experience, and some form of extracurricular involvement, one of the biggest differentiators becomes the quality of your written application. Crafting strong applications are an art in themselves and the writing style is quite specific and can take time to master, so please do not beat yourself up, it’s not a reflection on you or your capabilities or potential.

author: effystonem92
content:
Appreciate the spirit of discussion! As someone who attended a Go8 university and completed almost all assessments through in-person closed/open book exams, I completely understand the frustration and sense of unfairness that can arise when academic marks are not moderated consistently across institutions or formats. However, in practice, I don’t believe this discrepancy plays as significant a role in graduate recruitment outcomes as it may have in the past, even among top-tier firms.
For example, here’s stats from a top tier firm who took in around 50 clerks last year. Less than 50% went to USYD/UNSW – still a sizeable amount, but not the domination that you’d once expect for the Sydney process. Over 30% came from universities like UTS, Macquarie, WSU, Wollongong and others, with the remainder from interstate or international institutions. This trend isn’t isolated to just one firm either – similar data patterns can be seen across other firms as well. Of course, this doesn’t mean your university doesn’t matter at all, but perhaps I oversimplified a bit in that it's moreso that the emphasis on institutional prestige isn’t quite as decisive as it once was.

content:
If it’s any comfort, remember, it only takes one.
I know someone who’s always been an exceptional candidate with outstanding stats, but not the strongest when it comes to navigating written applications. When applying to the Big 4 accounting firms in their second year, they landed just one interview from a firm, but converted it to an offer. Same thing happened with their BBIB cycle in their third year – one interview, one offer. During clerkship season in their fourth year, they applied to over 20 firms and again received only one interview offer, which was from a T6, which they converted into a clerkship. And finally, when they applied to MBB in their final year, they only got one interview, and yes, turned it into an offer where they've now been working there happily for many years. It sounds beyond ridiculous, I couldn’t make it up even if I tried!
I also have many friends who received “only” one or two interviews during clerkships, but still converted those into offers. It can feel incredibly disheartening, especially when you see others posting about having 10+ interviews, but this actually happens far more often than you’d think so please try not to lose hope!

author: lwoods420
content:
Hi Guys,
I know a lot of people are probably anxiously watching Whirlpool, so I thought I'd make a list based off what people in chat have said thus far and what I have heard. So far:
- GNT: Psychometric Test released on 14 July (Rejection emails were sent too) - Bakers: Released on 14 July - NRF: Released on 17 July (No rejection email) - Turks: (Supposedly) Released 17 July - W&C: Video Interview released 17 July (Rejection emails sent) awaiting 2nd round - HFW: Released on 18 July (Rejection emails sent) - H&W: Released on 18 July (Rejection emails sent) - TG: Released 21 or 23 July (?) - MO: Released 21 July (?) - Corrs: Released 21 July (Rejection emails sent) - HSF: Released 21 July (Rejection emails sent) - B&B: Released 24 July (Rejection emails sent) - Minters: Released 24 July (Rejection emails sent) - Clifford Chance: Released 24 July (Rejection emails sent?) - KWM: Released 24 July (Notified by calling, unsure about rejections) - Maddocks: Released 25 July - Allens: Released 25 July (Rejection emails sent) - K&L Gates: (Supposedly) Released 28 July (No rejections as of yet) - DLA Piper: Released 28 July (Rejection emails sent) - Ashurst: Released 29 July (Rejection emails sent) - Gadens: Released 29 July (Rejection emails sent)
Unconfirmed / Waiting (as of 5pm 29 July):
- ClUtz (?) -  A&O Shearman - Barry Nilsson - Hamers - HWL Ebsworth - JWS (?) - Jones Day (?) - McIntyre Legal - Morgan + English - McR - Clyde & Co
Best of luck to everyone else waiting or to those heading into the interview stage – you got it!

author: effystonem92
content: For G+T VI, IMHO, be ready for at least one of the questions to be a more social or unexpected question, something a bit off the beaten path. A few years ago, for example, one of the questions was 'What is your most embarrassing moment?'. They tend to include a question like that every year to showcase your personality and see how well you can think on your feet, rather than flogging x4 standard behaviourals. That said, I'm speaking as someone who's no longer directly involved so this may longer be accurate, and unfortunately, you're not likely to get many people offering tips or giving you a heads-up advantage on online forums which is understandable, but hopefully this is somewhat of help.

author: Lemons010
content:
G+T is no longer doing video interviews anymore, it’s just the Super Saturday event which involves a 45 minute interview with 2 partners, an individual assessment and a group assessment.

author: mikoraiden
content: +Barry Nilsson

author: overthinker123
content:
mikoraiden writes...
it's a written assessment and role play – any advice (even from other firms) would mean a lot!
Haven't done C&C AC, but general advice. Brush up on your affidavit skills, email etiquette and legal language. For any group assessment, do not worry about being talked over and focus on getting your point across. Firms prefer those that are collaborative and open-minded as opposed to those that are dismissive. If it's a negotiation exercise, they are not looking at seeing you 'win' but how collaborative each party is in approaching a solution that is in both clients' interests.
Not sure if that helps, but I hope you got some insight.

thread_title: 2026 Aus Government Graduate Program Legal Stream
author: Big Poppa Flex
content:
The written assessment was hard.
What was asked in the activity was pretty straightforward. But having to read the facts and law and write all the issues they wanted me to address was not easy.
Also add the fact that there is no spell check (the first screen warned if you change windows the assessment would freeze, so can't type in word) and the timer is invisible because the text box needs scrolling the timer off view. Scrolling back and forth to timer adds a few seconds because of the amount of text you have to scroll past.  And the text box only shows 2 lines at a time. But at least you can copy from the facts/law and paste it if you have to.

thread_title: 2026 Aus Government Graduate Program Legal Stream
author: leospaceman
content:
Hey mate, per merit pool email 16.07.25: Should you be successfully matched to a participating agency, you will be contacted by them directly from mid-August onwards to confirm your interest in taking up a graduate role in 2026.
Question: Does anyone know of people who were merit pooled but not matched? Or rough percentages?
Edit: may have answered my question. Data stream says ‘Last year, more than 200 candidates out of 500 who made it to the merit pool did not receive any job offers’. The HR person on the thread said similar proportions are seen across streams.
I think it would be in one’s best interests to keep applying elsewhere, just in case.

thread_title: 2026 Aus Government Graduate Program Legal Stream
author: staticdesign
content: FYI, there is a FOI request regarding the 2024/25 AGGP – Legal Stream which provides insight into the numbers re preferencing and MP ( https://www.ag.gov.au/sites/ default/files/2024-10/FOI24- 411%20-%20Disclosure%20log%2 0documents%20-%20date%20of%20access%20031024.PDF ). On page 79 of the PDF, it says there were 278 and 241 candidates in the Merit Pool for the 2024 and 2025 graduate programs, respectively.

Best of luck!!

author: Clerkshippy
content: Good luck! As someone who went through this process and is now on the other side – it's a marathon and not a sprint. Be kind to yourselves and don't treat the word on this forum as gospel (you never know who is trolling...). You've got this!

author: Anonuserrecovery
content: Does anyone know if final year students in Melb, if fortunate to eventually receive a grad offer, can start earlier instead of waiting a year?

author: staticdesign
content: Hi @Anonuserrecovery I don't think so. The LIV guidelines ( https://www.liv.asn.au/downl oad.aspx?DocumentVersionKey= 31f602a6-4dae-406b-80b7-2c90c530f938 ) say grad offers to clerks can only be made during the priority offer period. The date for that is set yearly (usually early August) and comes before market grad applications open.

author: kstrat
content: I know people who have been able to start in February after doing a summer 1 or 2 clerkship, but depends on the firm's needs. It's worth expressing your interest to HR at the end of your clerkship.

thread_title: Department of Justice Graduate Progran 2026 WA
author: Researcher
content:
I believe it’s a merit pool…
“This pool will be open for a period of 12 months from the day after the breach of standard claim period closes. The Department of Justice uses recruitment pools to build a bank of talent for future opportunities. Applicants found suitable in this pool, may be considered for subsequent, similar vacancies, with the Department of Justice for the duration of the pool. ”
Source: https://search.jobs.wa.gov.au /page.php?pageID=160&windowUID=0&AdvertID=375610

author: harveyspectre41
content: Hey guys reminder to not treat whirlpool as a reliable source re offers and rejections. As someone who went through this process last year, there were people who trolled about offers from Big6 Firms being released, when they actually hadn't yet. It's frustrating that people do this, when the process itself is already so stressful and anxiety inducing. But just use this as a reminder to remain positive until you yourself have seen an offer or rejection explicitly being received to either yourself or a mate.

author: clerkshipapplicant
content: I got an interview email at 7:30pm for HSF but my application's status is still 'submitted' :) Also I was wondering if anyone could give me any insight as to what a clerkship information evening entails? Should I continue to research and be prepared to network or is it strictly presentations etc?

author: Goodanonnnnnn
content: Hahahah probably! Do all of your status’ still say ‘submitted’? Realllyyy holding out hope for HSF!

author: harveyspectre41
content: @clerkshipapplicant Congrats on getting an interview with HSF! That's a huge achievment in itself and you should be so proud. I can't speak for all firms, but for the firm's whose cocktail information evenings I attended last year – it was a mix of presentations / networking. Usually starts off with presentations and info about the firm, then you break out into a mixed networking setting, where you have the chance to interact with HR, Grads, Partners, Associates and fellow students. So I think doing research and having some questions prepared is good :)

author: dogster99
content: @justhappy2bhere fwiw the process is very arbitrary – i knew of people with fantastic grades/ec/work experience who didn't even sniff an interview at some places. conversely, you just need one place to like you for things to pan out. in terms of practical advice try to get your cv and cover letter looked at by someone in a firm or someone who's successfully clerked before. your student law society should have career events that do something similar if you don't know anyone personally. currently final year and in a similar boat to you (decent wam, good work experience) and have managed to get some interviews after not getting anything last year. also some places are still yet to get back afaik

author: PersonalInjury
content:
justhappy2bhere writes...
hello. wondering if anyone is aware of the effect of selecting a clerkship location preference. is it likely the case that if you preference one over another then the firm will only consider you for that preference as, on face value, they might assume that you are not likely to commit to a grad role to the 2nd preference?
ummm if its a big six, they normally only let u have one preference for location, the clerk location = ur grad location generally some of them say in their apps that u should only apply to one state, if not, then u can probably apply to diff states to answer ur question tho, i dont think it'll make a difference, they'll presume that u only commit to a grad role in the same location as where u do ur clerkship even if u dont select a location pref. most grads are drawn from the clerkship cohort anyways so unless u ask to move for grad, you'll be at the same place.

author: firewood300503
content:
Offer day is tomorrow! I just wanted to send a little reminder to everyone (including myself) to take a deep breath and be proud of yourselves. You’ve worked so hard to get to this point, and that’s an achievement in itself. Getting this far in the clerkship process is no small feat, and you should all be incredibly proud.
Whatever happens tomorrow, remember that you are more than capable, and your worth is not defined by one outcome. Keep a positive mindset and back yourselves 100%! Also remember that everything happens for a reason, and sometimes the best opportunities come in unexpected ways. What’s meant for you won’t pass you by, so trust the process.
You’ve all got this, and I’m rooting for each and every one of you!

author: Jelly55
content:
Hi I am very stressed final year student, I literally have 6 months of study left. I really want to apply for and work at a top tier law firm I just missed out on a clerkship for one (had interviews for like 4 top tier). I am scared to try for graduate positions given I feel like I don't stand out amongst other candidates given I have 2 years worth of legal assistant experience and, really good grades, a few extracurricular including mooting experience, but that's it.
So I am thinking should I extend my degree for another semester so I can get in more experience before I apply or is that a waste of time. I only have 3 units left.
Also do you think it is impossible to get a graduate position at a top tier without having direct law clerk or paralegal experience? My work as a legal assistant encompasses stuff these roles would do but I don't have the official title and feel that is a flaw.

author: suspicious fish
content:
Hi
So I am thinking should I extend my degree for another semester so I can get in more experience before I apply or is that a waste of time. I only have 3 units left.
I wouldn't extend the degree unless you believe that it will somehow help you gain additional experience. As a final year you're unlikely to qualify for clerkships, so I'd only think that extending your degree was worth it if it made you a penultimate student and gave you another crack at summer clerkships this year. I have on occasion seen students add an honours year or something to that effect to do this.
Jelly55 writes...
Also do you think it is impossible to get a graduate position at a top tier without having direct law clerk or paralegal experience?
I wouldn't be too worried about this part if you end up choosing not to extent your degree in to next year – it is definitely possible (if slightly tricky). I would make sure to clearly articulate what the legal assistant experience involved to demonstrate that you've been performing the same core tasks if this is the case.
It sounds like your profile itself is fine (and you'll likely get interviews in the grad process). However, if you've missed out on internships having had several interviews the main thing I'd focus on is spending a lot of time on interview prep.

author: shepherdfan
content:
Jelly55 writes...
Also do you think it is impossible to get a graduate position at a top tier without having direct law clerk or paralegal experience?
Do not extend your degree. You are hurting yourself financially by doing so and extending is something you need to explain to an employer.
Apply for top tier, mid tier and boutique firms. Take a grad job where you can get it. Just because you start out at XYZ firm does not mean you cannot move to a top tier in due course. Most lawyers leave top tier between 2-5 years PQE. Top tiers then hire from mid tiers and boutiques to fill those roles.
Just because you do not get in on the first go, does not mean you can never work there.

thread_title: 2025 Aus Government Graduate Program Legal Stream
author: Username unavailable
content: I don't think everyone who received offers got them from top preferences, but I'm not entirely sure how the offers were worked out from our preferences. My understanding is that each department that has sent offers so far (unclear if they all have) sent enough to fill all their places. I don't think they reserved any spots for second round and assuming spots were accepted some departments wont send any more offers from this point. That said, some people will likely reject those offers or ultimately not stay in the job if they fail security checks or have other issues. This will be why there were positions being offered in October/November last year.

author: Sadgraduate
content: Thought I’d offer hope and perspective to those that have missed out on an offer – I graduated 3 years ago and missed out on grad positions in my grad year. I was fortunate enough to be picked up as a consultant at a Big 4 company and have worked there for 3 years in a field that is not related to legal at all. Yesterday I finally got that offer for a grad position at a law firm. Work on building out your resume and add unique experiences so that your resume stands out, you’ll get to where you want eventually. You can also look to completing your PLT at your own cost and once you have your PLT you’re much more hireable to law firms.

How important are grades once you get to the interview/merit pooling stage?

Still waiting, obviously nothing I can do now, but just interested in your views.

author: A3C2
content: @midsummer I don't think grades are that important once you get to the merit pool. If it was important, then they would have eliminated you in the first round. You made it to the interview stage means you are a suitable candidate for them.

author: norming
content: I agree, if they were going to take issue with you academic record, they wouldn’t have progressed you past the first round or two. Seems like a waste of everyone’s time if they were to reject you on the basis of information they had at the very beginning of the process

author: animatedblob
content:
A3C2 writes...
@midsummer I don't think grades are that important once you get to the merit pool. If it was important, then they would have eliminated you in the first round. You made it to the interview stage means you are a suitable candidate for them.
This is good advice. Your grades will be part of your overall picture, but if you interview well (and you've already made it into the merit pool) they'll fall into the background.
I've worked in the public service, and you'd be amazed at how low the caliber can be, particularly at the highest levels-- I was once line managed in the public service by a guy who didn't finish high school.
This wouldn't be a problem at all if he was a talented under-achiever, but his literacy levels were so low he struggled to compose an email. However, he was good looking, charismatic, and most importantly, had powerful friends. This also kind of explains why government are so dependent on consulting firms such as PwC-- capacity can be shockingly low at the upper levels so they need to pay experts to do their thinking for them.
If you are literate, have a degree and can pass for smart and personable, you're in with a good chance.

I’m assuming end of this week/next week we will receive an update as to whether we have made it to the merit pool? The candidate pack says they’re doing interviews until week commencing 29 May, merit pool is week commencing 29 May and matching is week commencing 5 June

author: ZeroLithium
content:
midsummer writes...
How important are grades once you get to the interview/merit pooling stage?
My grades are not great (low credit with 3 fails in my 5 year double degree) but I think I did OK in my interview/assessment.
Still waiting, obviously nothing I can do now, but just interested in your views.
Grades will not matter if you have been found suitable for a position. If after all the stages (e.g. Assessment Centres/Interviews), you make it in the merit pool, you have a decent shot at being offered a position once the line areas review and select those who have been placed in the pool.

author: ZeroLithium
content:
bzbka writes...
Hey guys,
With preferences, if we select 'yes' to relocation, how likely is it that they would make you relocate to another state if we're from NSW or VIC? Anyone heard from anyone who has done a grad program in gov?
I'm just wondering if they would have a discussion with us first after the merit pool about relocation or if they would simply decide for us if we tick yes in the form.
Thanks!
Depends on where the position is located. There may be some teams who are happy to have team members work flexibly interstate, and some which are Canberra based, and you must be physically there.
Most grad programs will ask that you relocate to Canberra, but some of the bigger Departments which have offices/sites in other states (such as Services Australia or Defence) may have the opportunity for people to remain in their home state. If in doubt, talk to the grad team about what options there may be, but be prepared for them to ask you to relocate.

author: anonymous126
content:
Just a heads up for anyone who may still be considering whether to accept their AGD offer.
It is a horrible place to work, the EP team is terrible and highly incompetent. You are just treated as cheap labour. The department itself is not culturally safe, is a mix match of abilities and at the end of the day really only wonts privileged, straight, white, neurotypical male lawyers working for them.
I would only accept the offer if you already live in Canberra or possibly Sydney if you don't mind moving. Otherwise accept something else and if you want to work for the department just apply through normal channels at the APS 5 classification (although I would recommend against it!)

author: ravencraw
content: Anyone else feeling a little imposter syndrome from not having enough interviews ://

author: primafacie11
content:
ravencraw writes...
Anyone else feeling a little imposter syndrome from not having enough interviews ://
Well, the very definition of imposter syndrome suggests that such feelings arise "despite evidence to the contrary". It's valid to feel negative following rejection, in fact it's a natural human response. However, you've made it this far into a law degree which alone speaks to your skill set and work ethic. Unfortunately this is a competitive process due to a surplus of imminent law grads. Considering this context, rejections are merely an indication that firms have reached capacity and cannot offer you a space, not necessarily that you aren't qualified or aren't suited to the role. Keep your chin up and remember this is not the be all and end all of your career. If it doesn't work out this time around, more opportunities will come your way. This process definitely tests our self-confidence, but if it's any consolation, you're not alone.

author: shepherdfan
content:
This sub brings back memories. Don't be afraid to be yourself in interviews and show personality. Believe it or not firms don't want robots. What they want is hard working people eager to learn who can work well as part of a team. This means it is ok to showcase your interest in everything from sporting teams to ballet to art. I actually secured my grad role at a top tier because I corrected the Partner on when X football team last won a premiership. He told me I was wrong, I asked him if he would bet the graduate position on it and I was correct...
Also (and I know everyone says this) but if you don't get into a top tier for a grad program it does not mean your career is over. I did top tier for the first 10 years of my career (and it was excellent) and have been a Partner at a national for almost a decade. However, I have worked with many people at all levels who did not go the traditional route and still ended up as a Partner in a top tier or other amazing firm. Many others who started at smaller firms have moved to amazing in-house or commercial roles.
Be you, give it your best shot and remember law provides numerous career options, many of which you do not see until you are 5+ years in the profession.

author: watermelon123
content: @shepherdfan This is great advice, thank you :) Being yourself is important and if that's the reason you don't get hired, you don't want to spend your whole career faking a persona.

Given the majority of clerks tend to come from these universities, the GPA requirement for non-Go8 students can often be higher. This is just my understanding, but I could be completely mistaken.

author: Jelly55
content: My GPA is a 6 I got 4 top tier interviews and 4 mid tier I think what makes up for my average grades is I have a bit of legal experience, but different things stand out for different people so you never know who will get in and who won’t.

author: lawclerk-2024
content: Guys GPA of 6 is absolutely amazing! This is what I'm talking about. People saying 6 isn't amazing or 6 is average grades and you have to make up for it somewhere else is so crazy! This whole competitive clerkship process and emphasis on grades being above a certain level makes people think all the hard work they have put in this far isn't enough (at law school). I know some incredibly smart people that would make amazing lawyers but don't have a GPA above 6. Everyone should be so proud of what they have achieved so far. Even just going through this process is such an accomplishment in itself! Is there anyone on here with a GPA below 6 and got an interview at a top tier?

author: Goldenm2020
content:
Right here! My GPA is below 6 and still got few interviews at top tier firms.

Everyone is unique and different, never let your grade determines who you are!!

author: shepherdfan
content: For clarity, if you have already had interviews and a Partner is following up with you for a further coffee, you have the grad role. Do not underestimate how competitive top tier partners are. If Clutz overs a grad role to the same person as HSF, they get very happy when the person chooses Clutz and vice versa. I have my own firm views as to which firms I would choose in Brisbane, but will keep those to myself!

author: Goldenm2020
shepherdfan
content:
if you have already been through the full interview process, offers are coming this week and the Partner wants a coffee with you then you will be offered a grad role at that firm.
You need to understand Partners work 60+ hours per week. Taking time out to have a coffee with someone is actually a considered action. You don't do this after they go through an interview process unless you want to hire that person.
Common sense.
If you want to be a great lawyer – always put yourself in the other side's shoes and think about their motivations.

author: shepherdfan
content:
Clutz is sick of losing grads to HSF, KMW and Allens. In Brisbane Clutz and Minters are 70% government work / projects. If you want corporate, finance etc you avoid them. If you want employment, planning or projects great firms
And the more time they put into you the more they want you. In any clerkship group there are standouts a firm must have. Usually 5-10 clerks max. After that there is a bigger list they fill the next 5-40 places from

author: winterblues87
content:
This is a message to anyone who is looking to apply for clerkships next year!
I remember feeling daunted by the process, thinking my grades or experience weren’t enough. It’s easy to self-reject when comparing yourself to others, but don’t let that hold you back.
I applied to 9 firms, received 5 interview offers – 3 from top-tier firms and 2 from mid-tiers – and I received offers from all 5.
For reference, my GPA is 5.4, and I’ve had a year and a half of legal experience. It’s taken me 4 years to complete 3 years of my law degree.
My advice for future applicants is to lean into your strengths, even those outside of law. I have a passion for the arts, and I made sure to highlight that in my applications and interviews. Many firms emphasise being yourself, and if you focus on your strengths, draw from your personal experiences (both good and bad), and highlight what truly inspires you, you will stand out.
I hope this encourages some of you to apply next year. Everyone’s journey is different, and you don’t need to be the “poster law student” to succeed.

author: bananageorge
content:
^ The above applies only if you fit neatly into rigid and predefined diversity categories (there are grants, awards, etc. at stake!)
(How do I know? I was waitlisted for my clerkship offers, and ultimately none came through—even after being told I interviewed really well. I have a slightly better GPA than winterblues87 [~5.5], have more legal work experience, have battled through and overcome extremely difficult circumstances throughout my degree, and have very impressive extracurriculars).
Remember, to get opportunities in corporate law you need one or more of three things: good grades (>6 GPA), connections, or ticking enough established diversity boxes.
last updated – posted 2024-Oct-18, 6:16 pm AEST posted 2024-Oct-18, 6:16 pm AEST

author: Bondi99
content:
Can someone please let me know whether the following, from Jones Day's websites, means that everyone who applies to their clerkships is invited to attend the information evening? aka an email invite doesn't mean you're through to the next round...
Q. What format does the recruitment process take?
A. We start our recruitment process by inviting candidates to our Clerkship Information Evening where we tell you more about life at Jones Day. You'll hear firsthand accounts from our graduates, associates and partners. Following this, there are two rounds of interviews for our Clerkship programs. These can be in-person or online and will both be with two senior lawyers or partners. They will last approximately 30-40 minutes. The interviewers will be assessing candidates against the competencies that are essential to be a successful summer clerk, graduate and solicitor at Jones Day.
Before the interviews, all candidates have the chance to chat with a graduate or junior associate who can answer any questions the candidate may have about life at Jones Day.

author: primafacie11
content:
I just did VI for Minters (QLD stream) and questions were mainly behavioural, requiring me to give examples of how I responded in the following: 1. challenging situation; 2. Situation where circumstances change and necessary to adapt; 2. situation where had to establish a relationship/build rapport quickly.
The only other question was "why commercial law and why our firm"
I have no legal experience but could answer all of these questions based on my other work experience or university.
These are all predictable interview questions that someone preparing thoroughly for a VI would likely anticipate.

author: Bondi99
content: If VIs are still open for ME in QLD I probably wouldn’t post the questions. It’ll just disadvantage yourself because everyone will be able to have responses ready - but if it’s closed ur fine haha

author: Kapool
content:
Did anyone get an interview from Allens  with less than 76 wam?
The whole focus on wam is totally ridiculous. Barely any difference between low 70s and up. Why focus on something like exams/assingment when that has no bearing on what actual legal practice is like…  ppl with 80s wams are probably just studying all the time anyway – lawyers actually need to know how to talk to people

author: gimmeofferpls
content:
Kapool writes...
Barely any difference between low 70s and up. Why focus on something like exams/assingment when that has no bearing on what actual legal practice is like…  ppl with 80s wams are probably just studying all the time anyway
I respectfully disagree with what you just said, as it seems to lack consideration for those with an 80+ WAM. While I don't personally have an 80 WAM, I know someone who does. This friend works three days a week as a paralegal, stays late to study, and still maintains an 80+ WAM.
Unfortunately, there's a significant difference between a low 70 and a high 70 WAM. If you have a low 70s WAM, you might only be in the top 50% of your cohort. However, with a 78 or 79 WAM, you’re likely in the top 10%.
One last thing: instead of making rude comments, you should take this opportunity to reflect on yourself. Self-reflection is important for anyone aspiring to be a lawyer.

author: primafacie11
content:
Kapool writes...
they will more often be privileged students from more wealthy backgrounds
This is totally valid, and I don't agree with any firm using an automatic WAM cut off (although appreciate that TT need some mechanism for efficiency considering the sheer volume of applicants). Your comment just rubbed the wrong way for those who have performed really well academically without coming from a privileged background... Privilege in the law is insidious and should be called out – but not by bringing everyone down!

author: Goldenm2020
content:
I appreciate when firms ask to input any extenuating circumstances into the application, however it is actually unclear how it is used to assess one’s application. The transparency around this process is never great.
The nature of application process, which is heavily concentrated on interview, vs assessment centres means they have to reject large volume of applicants in the first round.
As someone from GO8 and who needs to work and have family responsibilities, the application process is far from great. There are amazing people with high WAMs or people have connections in the firm, I think it is just how the world works. There can never be full equality, however it is just a clerkship, not getting it does not mean your legal career is over. Lmao there are so many other pathways.
The Big Laws pride themselves on diversity and inclusion, however in my view it is more of a PR stunt rather than anything else. Just look at the amount of grads leaving after 2 years…….

author: o2o3
content:
If you've missed out on a clerkship, don't be disheartened. You've just missed out on an internship, not a career in law. The process is very arbitrary and unequal.
Clerkships (especially top-tier clerkships) are just the start of a pipeline that funnels starry-eyed young 20s H1/H2A graduates into working 12-hour days and weekends until they have sucked every last bit of life out of them for big corporations. Burnout is a given and most end up leaving. It is not for everyone. There is more to law than BigLaw and there is more than one way there.
I know this because I speak to lawyers about their mental health everyday.

author: legallyaussie
content:
Thanks for the kind words, o2o3. Ngl, after the first few rejections, I was seriously down on myself. Now, I'm more accepting. I'll probably look for a paralegal position or something and try again next year.
I'm genuinely interested in commercial law and have a serious work ethic. I hope to inherit a 12-hour-a-day position from the first wave of grads to burnout. It will take longer than the traditional clerk -> grad path, though.

content: what is everyone’s opinion on what the true big 6 actually are? Can someone list what they think the rankings are in order because it’s different everywhere I look

author: Goldenm2020
content:
The big 3: KWM,HSF,Allens are great firms to choose if you can. Within those, KWM’s Asia connection is good if you want to potentially work in Asia in the future. The other two all got British links and are great firms.
Clutz got more gov work so if you value work life balance, working in the gov sphere would give you a bit more breath in life. However Clutz I believe got the lowest pay and less perks then other.
Then you have Minters, Ashurst.
Corrs and G+T is at the T6 level as well.

author: Hopeforanoffer
content:
I’m curious to hear others' thoughts on this. Everyone keeps saying interviews are just a vibe check, but if someone has a lower WAM but does better in the interview, would they really be chosen over someone with a higher wam and more work experience? It seems strange to me that decisions would be based entirely on a 30 minute interview.
I didn’t get through any firms that have two round interviews, and it’s stressing me out as offer day approaches.

author: Hopeforanoffer
content: Also does anyone know how likely it is to get an offer from Clutz if you’ve made it to the interview stage?

author: auslaw003
content:
Hopeforanoffer writes...
I’m curious to hear others' thoughts on this. Everyone keeps saying interviews are just a vibe check, but if someone has a lower WAM but does better in the interview, would they really be chosen over someone with a higher wam and more work experience? It seems strange to me that decisions would be based entirely on a 30 minute interview.
My understanding is that if you have made it through to interviews, your WAM/GPA and work experience are good enough to receive an offer. The purpose of the interview would primarily be to assess your soft skills, and well as your aspirations for wanting to work in law and at that specific company. In saying that, the interviewing partner might find applicants with higher WAMs to be more 'impressive' and hence be more inclined to accept them, but that's just me speculating.

author: MarySmith333
content: Anyone ever heard of a firm letting someone accept a late clerkship offer? I.e. someone rejected the initial offer but then had a change of mind?  How understanding do you think firms would be in this case?

author: suckiton
content: too little too late

author: auslaw003
content:
MarySmith333 writes...
Anyone ever heard of a firm letting someone accept a late clerkship offer? I.e. someone rejected the initial offer but then had a change of mind?  How understanding do you think firms would be in this case?
I wouldn't think they would be too understanding tbh, unless they were desperate for more numbers (bear in mind though, they usually over-offer, estimating that a certain % will reject them). Of course, if you rejected them due to personal/family circumstances (and this was communicated to them), rather than simply because you wished to clerk at another firm, I presume they would make every effort to accommodate you where possible.
last updated – posted 2024-Sep-17, 7:12 pm AEST posted 2024-Sep-17, 7:12 pm AEST

author: Constant_Reader
content:
Hey @Midsummer, what Major Weetbix said: it is often about luck.
I would also add that graduate programs are not the be all and end all. They are great, but there are plenty of smaller firms who take on graduates and a lot of them don’t really care about your transcript. Tbh what they’re really looking for are people who are team-oriented and good to work with. You can train people how to draft legal docs and run matters, but you can’t train someone to be a respectful and decent human being. Anyone here ever worked with someone who yells and screams, or is unhelpful, or has zero consideration for their team? They are an employer’s nightmare.
To that end – a transcript is not really a good indicator of how successful you will be in your career. So if it doesn’t pan out with any of the graduate programs you’ve applied for, don’t let that dissuade you. Major Weetbix hit the nail on the head: just keep applying for every grad/paralegal role you come across, and you will get there.
Best of luck, and fingers crossed

author: almostdone
content:
Hi midsummer,
Unfortunately rejection is part of the process.
My advise if you are currently not worming in tbe legal sector and are unsuccessful this round is reaching out to smaller law firms and the partners of practice areas you are interested in. I have found this is more successful than competing with the state. There are tons of law firms that do not go through the Law Society's deadlines as well.
I have been rejected plenty of times from clerk/grad roles. It's important to remember that each rejection is a learning opportunity and a reflection of an imperfect system.
It's a marathon not a sprint, there are plenty of alternative ways to become a lawyer outside of getting a grad role in your dream firm.
Hope this is helpful!

author: Constant_Reader
content: Well said!

author: mew2
content: love the encouragement !!! :)

author: Sydgrad2024
content:
Hey Midsummer,
Just reiterating what everyone has said. A graduate program is not the be all and end all. Just because you don’t get one doesn’t mean you won’t have an amazing career. There are so many avenues to go down.
I know rejection can be super tough. So I hope you’re okay but just know it doesn’t mean you aren’t going to do amazing things!!

author: almostdone
content:
LAW WAM 75
Responses need to be personal and if possible link it to a specific commercial reason or purpose.
So don't just say I'm interested in commercial law because I studied finance and law.
You are multidimensional and your response can and should touch on this. It's hard to give advise in this area though without your specific responses.
If you'd like to dm me I would be happy to share my advice and the strategies I have found helpful in getting to the next round.
